title: House of Blue Fire
author: Mark Morris
filename: 152 - House of Blue Fire - Mark Morris_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
1. EXT. GROUNDS OF A TUMBLEDOWN COUNTRY HOTEL
(FX: THIN, DESOLATE WIND; RUSTLING LEAFLESS TREES AND BUSHES.
FOOTSTEPS ON STONY GROUND, TRUDGING TO STOP)
(CALLING, A LITTLE HESITANTLY) Hello? Anyone at home?
(FX: RUSTY SCRAPE AS SHE TUGS ON A BELL-PULL; OFF/SOMEWHERE IN THE HOUSE — A BELL CLANGS)
Someone...? Anyone...?
(FX: FROM INSIDE, THE APPROACH OF MEASURED FOOTSTEPS ON A STONE FLOOR. CLUNK OF A HEAVY LATCH; THE DOOR CREAKS OPEN)
(UNFLUSTERED) Welcome, Miss. Won’t you come in?
(GRATEFUL; SURPRISED) Thank you.
FX: WALKS THROUGH INTO:
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page
2. INT. MAIN HALLWAY/RECEPTION (CONTINUOUS
(FX: DOOR CLOSES WITH A CREAK AND BANG. VOICES ECHO SLIGHTLY,
SPACE, EMPTINESS)
I trust you had a pleasant journey, Miss?
I don’t know. I can’t remember how I got here. Were you expecting me?
Of course.
See, the thing is.. this is going to sound really odd, but I have no idea where I am.
Bluefire House.
Can’t say that makes things any clearer. I’m guessing from reception desk and everything that this is a hotel, right?
The evidence would seem to suggest so.
It’s very quiet, though. Have I arrived out of season?
We're simply a little off the beaten track here, Miss.
Well, what does that mean?
(FX: WALKING TO DESK) The Master will explain everything.
(FX: FOLLOWING SOAMES) The Master?
(FX: STOPPING) At dinner.
I’m a guest, then? Do I need to sign in?
the
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 4
That won’t be necessary, Miss. (FX: OPENING DRAWER BY DESK,
WRISTBAND) The Master simply asked that you wear this:
A plastic wristband? (READING) ‘18’. What’s ‘18’? My room number?
It would seem so, Miss.
But won’t I need a key, too? To get into my room, I mean?
All doors are open, here at Bluefire House.
Isn’t that a security risk? What sort of a hotel is this?
The Master will —
(INTERRUPTING) I know — explain everything. So what time is dinner? When do I meet this ‘Master’ of yours?
Seven o’clock sharp, Miss.
Seven. Right. And what time is it now?
FX: OFF — ON CUE, A GRANDFATHER CLOCK WHIRRS AND STRIKES FIVE
(RUEFULLY) So what do I do for the next two hours?
I’1ll show you to your room.
(UNCERTAINLY) I don’t seem to have any luggage.
That’s quite all right, Miss.
(THE WEIRDNESS SUDDENLY GETTING TO HER) Why can’t I remember anything, Mr...?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 5
Soames, Miss.
. Mr Soames. Why can’t I remember how I got here? (GASPS) Why can’t I even remember my name?
PAUSE
This way, Miss. Your room is just up here.
(FX: SOAMES LEADS THE WAY, ASCENDING CREAKING STAIRS. SALLY
Can’t we use the lift?
No need.
FX: FADE OUT ASCENDING FOOTSTEPS
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 6
3. INT. UPPER LANDING. SALLY’S BEDROOM
FX: CREAK OF AN OPENING DOOR
The accommodation is a little basic, I’m afraid.
No, it’s lovely. I’ve never slept in a four-poster bed.
I’m afraid the amenities are not all they could be. We have no electricity here.
I’1ll be fine, Mr Soames, honestly. I’ve roughed it in far worse places. (SUDDEN REALISATION) Oh! How did I know that when I don’t even know who I am?
I really can’t say, Miss.
Can’t or won’t?
I’m sorry, Miss. It’s not my place.
(SIGHS) All right, Mr Soames. I don’t want to get you into trouble. But at least tell me this: am I in danger?
Not from me, Miss.
Who, then? The Master?
I’m sure the Master has your best interests at heart. Now, if you’1ll excuse me...
You’re not leaving me, are you?
Just ring if you need anything, Miss.
(ANXIOUS) And you won't... forget me, will you?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 7
Forget you?
Forget I’m here?
No, Miss.
Good. Thanks, Mr Soames. I’1ll see you later.
(FX: HE RETREATS, CLOSING THE DOOR. FADE OUT RECEDING
LONG SIGH AS...
FX: SHE SITS ON THE BED; CREAK OF BED-SPRINGS
(MURMURS) So. What now? (ANOTHER LONG EXHALATION) Just... keep it together, girl. Try to work this thing out...
(FX: OFF/OUTSIDE — SCAMPERING, CHILD-LIKE FOOTSTEPS, AS THOUGH A TRIO OF CHILDREN ARE RUNNING UP TO HER DOOR. A PAUSE, THEN... A
AGAINST THE DOOR, AS THOUGH ONE OF THE CHILDREN HAS FALLEN, OR BEEN PUSHED, AGAINST IT)
Hello?
(FX: MUFFLED, CHILD-LIKE GIGGLING, BUT DISTORTED, SLURRED,
Hello? Is anyone there?
(FX: SQUEAL OF BEDSPRINGS AS SHE RISES. FOOTSTEPS AS SHE CROSSES THE ROOM. A CREAK AS SHE OPENS THE DOOR. SILENCE)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 8
4. INT. UPPER LANDING OUTSIDE SALLY’S ROOM (CONTINUOUS
(CALLING SOFTLY) Hello?
FX: STEALTHY CLICK OF A CLOSING DOOR, A FEW FEET AWAY
I heard you — (FX: HURRIES DETERMINEDLY TO DOOR, STOPS) Room 13. Great. (FX: TAPS ON DOOR) Is someone in there?
SILENCE
O-kay...
FX: SHE TURNS THE HANDLE; DOOR CREAKS OPEN
(LOUDLY BEHIND HER) So...
(SHOCKED GASP) Oh my [God!] —
. who the hell are you?
(ANGRY) Did you have to creep up behind me like that? You scared me half to death!
(DISMISSIVELY) Sorry. So, you a guest here?
Sort of. I’ve just arrived. You?
Been here about an hour. You got a name?
I... don’t know.
Then you’ve got mind-wipe syndrome too. Damn. Was hoping you might know what’s going on.
sorry.
(NOTICING WRSITBAND) Old Lurch gave you a shackle, then?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 9
Shackle?
Wristband. Whatever. Room 18, right?
Yes.
I’m in 5. (THOUGHTFULLY) Weird, isn’t it?
What is?
Your room’s back there. But the one just beyond it is mine. Number 5.
What sort of place has rooms 5 and 18 right next to each other?
It don’t make sense. Nothing about all this makes sense. Have you seen anyone else since you got here? Apart from old Lurch, I mean?
No. But I heard something.
What sort of something?
I don’t know. Children. In here, I think.
Well, then. Guess we’d better take a look.
FX: CREAK AS RACHEL PUSHES THE DOOR FURTHER OPEN
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 10
5. INT. PLAYROOM (CONTINUOUS
Well, this’d be the place for them.
FX: FEET ON BARE BOARDS AS THEY ENTER
It’s a nursery. But these dolls look Victorian. That rocking horse too.
Yeah, no PS9s here. And it’s full of dust. You sure those kids came in here?
Well... I don’t suppose they can have, can they? I must have been mistaken.
Easily done, I s’pose. Spooky old place like this.
(FX: OFF, THE LID OF A BOX SUDDENLY FLIES OPEN WITH A BANG, AND WITH A LOUD, JUMP-OUT-OF-YOUR-SKIN ‘BOING’, A JACK-IN-THE-BOX
UPWARDS )
BOTH GIRLS JUMP, CRYING OUT
(LAUGHING WITH RELIEF) Oh, it’s only a jack-in-the-box. It frightened the living daylights out of me.
(ANGRY; SHE DOESN’T LIKE TO SHOW FEAR) What made it jump out like that? We were nowhere near it.
The vibrations of our footsteps, perhaps? The mechanism must be sensitive.
Well, there’s no-one here. Let’s go.
(FX: THEY CROSS THE ROOM AND EXIT, SHUTTING THE DOOR FIRMLY
THEM)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 11
6. INT. UPPER LANDING (CONTINUOUS
What now?
Let’s look around. Explore. Try to work out why we’re here.
Do you think we should?
Did Lurch tell you you shouldn’t?
Well... no, but-
(INTERRUPTING) That’s settled then.
(THOUGHTFULLY) Why do you think we’re here?
Dunno. Some kind of experiment maybe.
Experiment?
Yeah. You know. Brainwashing. Maybe we’re spies on a top secret mission. Or the victims of a mad scientist.
(LAUGHS) Sounds a bit far-fetched.
Yeah? So what do you reckon? What’s your theory?
I haven’t got one.
Right. Well, that’s useful. (SOFTENING A LITTLE) What do you remember?
Being scared. Running. Pushing my way through trees and bushes. Then I saw this house. (APOLOGETIC) That’s all, I’m afraid. What about you?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 12
I remember seeing the house. Knocking on the door. Old Lurch telling me I was expected.
That’s it?
That’s it. Before that there’s.. nothing. No memories except...
Except?
Except old Lurch seemed familiar. Just for a second, when he opened the door. Did you think that?
I don’t know.
Don’t know much, do you?
Well, neither do you.
We’re a right pair, aren’t we? (HARD) Maybe we ought to make old Lurch tell us.
How?
We could threaten him. Even hurt him a bit.
And you’d be prepared to do that, would you?
Why not?
Well, for one thing we’re not in any immediate danger. And for another, Mr Soames is our only potential ally.
He’s our only source of information too.
Except for the Master.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 13
Oh yeah. The mysterious Master. Can’t say I think much of him. Leaving us to stew in our own juices. Softening us up.
Or just allowing us to acclimatise before he makes his appearance?
Trusting little soul, aren’t you?
Not at all. I just don’t automatically think the worst of every Situation.
Thinking the worst is the only way to survive, darling.
If that’s how you think, I feel sorry for you.
Don’t patronise me.
I’m not. I just... Look. We’re in the same situation here. Let’s stick together, shall we? Support one another?
How do I know you’re not a plant? Put here to gain my trust?
Oh, you’re impossible!
Wary, that’s all.
How do I know you’re not here to destabilise me?
You don’t. Only I know that.
Exactly.
Okay. We’1ll stick together. But that doesn’t mean we have to trust each other. Agreed?
Agreed.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 14
FX: OFF/DISTANT — THE WHIRRING CLANK OF A DESCENDING LIFT
What’s that?
The lift! Must mean someone’s in it. Come on, let’s check it
out.
FX: FADE OUT RAPID FOOTSTEPS AS THEY HURRY AWAY
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 15
7. INT. CORRIDOR
(FX: THE DESCENDING WHIRR/CLANK OF THE LIFT, LOUDER NOW. FADE IN SALLY AND RACHEL’S APPROACHING FOOTSTEPS )
(RUNNING UP) At last. It was further away than I thought.
(BEHIND) Quick, press the button or the lift won’t stop.
(FX: SALLY’S RUNNING, THUMPING FOOTSTEPS. SHE REACHES THE LIFT, HITS THE BUTTON)
(PANTING) Made it!
Nice one.
FX: THE LIFT WHIRRS AND CLANKS TO A STOP. PAUSE
We'll have to open the gate ourselves. (EFFORT) Give me a hand, will you? This is really stiff.
(FX: BOTH GIRLS GRUNT AND GASP AS THEY HAUL OPEN AN OLD- FASHIONED, CONCERTINA-LIKE LIFT GATE, WHICH CLANKS RUSTILY)
Empty! After all that!
Filthy, too. Looks as though it hasn’t been used in years. Except...
Except what?
Look there. Footprints in the dust. Flat shoes. A man’s, possibly.
Probably just Soames.
Well, whoever it was, they must have got out higher up and then sent the lift down.
FX: A CREAK, AS OF STRAINING PULLEYS. THE LIFT SHUDDERS
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 16
Don’t sound too healthy, does it?
I think sticking to the stairs might be the safest option.
(TEASING) Not scared, are yer?
No. Just careful. Let’s close this and move on.
FX: CLANKING RATTLE AS THEY CLOSE THE LIFT GATE. FADE
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 17
8. INT. UPPER CORRIDOR
(FX: DOWNSTAIRS, CLOCK STRIKES ONCE FOR HALF-HOUR. FADE UP THE GIRLS’ FOOTSTEPS )
Half-past five.
Is that all? (STOPPING) It’s so piggin’ gloomy. Is there a way of making these gas lamps any brighter?
There should be a little wheel on the side.
FX: TINKERING
Well, that makes a big difference. Blimey, it’s like we’ve been thrown back to the Dark Ages.
Maybe we have.
Hey, look at this. Spooky old mirror. (SPOOKY VOICE) Mirror, mirror, on the wall, who’s the fairest of them all? (PAUSE) Guess not me, then.
FX: FOOTSTEPS RESUME
(THOUGHTFULLY) It’s interesting, isn’t it?
What is?
What we do and don’t remember. I’m guessing you remember what year it is?
Course. 2020.
Right. So you remember cities and cars and people? And politics and news, things like that?
Yeah.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 18
But can you remember where you live? Can you remember members of your family? What you ate for your last meal, even?
No...

So what we can remember is the infrastructure, the mechanics, of the society we live in, but not our place within it. For instance, I can easily picture.. a meadow on a sunny day. A football crowd. People eating in a restaurant. But I can’t relate any of those images to my personal experiences. As far as I’m concerned, I’m a.. void.
So what does that mean?
I don’t know. Maybe we don’t exist.
Don’t be soft. Course we exist! We’re here, aren’t we? My heart’s beating. If I pinch myself, it hurts.
(STOPPING) You know what frightens me more than anything? Being forgotten. I have this fear that one day I’1ll wake up and no- one will be able to see or hear me. I’1l just be... gone.
That won’t happen.
How do you know? We’re half-way there already. We have no focal point, no identity.
We have an identity. We just haven’t found it yet.
But what if we never find it?
We will.
But what if we don’t?
Look, just — keep calm, carry on. Let’s try some of these doors, shall we? (FX: TWISTS DOORKNOB. DOOR CREAKS OPEN INTO:)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 19
9. INT. OPERATING THEATRE (CONTINUOUS
Blimey, look at this!
It’s an operating theatre.
In a hotel? What the hell’s going on?
(FX: FOOTSTEPS ON TILED FLOOR AS SALLY CROSSES TO A SINK. SHE
UP A METAL TRAY, WHICH RATTLES WITH SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS )
There’s blood on these instruments. Fresh blood.
Nice. (FX: CREAK AS SHE LIFTS A METAL LID) Check out the waste bin. There’s blood on these scrubs, too. Remember what I said before? About experiments?
(SHUDDERS) Brrr...
You all right? Bit freaked out?
It’s not that. Didn’t you feel it?
Feel what?
Something cold. It just... brushed by me.
A draught, you mean? Got to expect it, old house like this. No central heating.
It didn’t feel like a draught.
So what’re you saying? That it was a ghost? (SPOOKY VOICE) Reaching out from beyond the grave with icy fingers?
Don’t make fun of me.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 20
Well, you got to admit, it’s a bit of a cliché. You’1l be seeing things next. Hearing unexplained noises.
(FX: OFF/OUTSIDE IN THE CORRIDOR — MUFFLED, CHILD-LIKE GIGGLING, AS BEFORE, THOUGH SLURRED, DISTORTED, SINISTER)
Like those, you mean?
Yeah. What the hell —
Come on.
FX: HURRIED FOOTSTEPS AS THEY EXIT INTO:
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 21
10. INT. UPPER CORRIDOR (CONTINUOUS
There’s nothing here. Which direction did it come from?
Down the corridor, look! Door closing!
(FX: A DOOR FURTHER ALONG THE CORRIDOR CLOSES WITH A SHARP BUT
CLICK)
(ANGRILY) Someone’s mucking us about!
FX: SHE STOMPS ACROSS, BANGS ON THE DOOR
Oi, you in there!
FX: TRIES DOORKNOB — OPENS WITH A CLICK AND A LOUD CREAK
(MUTTERS) Open sesame.
FX: WALKS THROUGH INTO:
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 22
11. INT. DERELICT INDOOR SWIMMING POOL (CONTINUOUS
(FX: THEIR FOOTSTEPS ECHO HOLLOWLY ON A TILED FLOOR AS THEY ENTER)
(SURPRISED) It’s a swimming pool! At least... I’m guessing there’s water under all those leaves.
(CLEARLY ON EDGE) Well, there’s obviously nothing here. Let’s
go.
What do you mean? We’ve barely had time for a proper look around.
(NERVOUSNESS MAKING HER ANGRY) What’s to see? A big empty room with a swimming pool in the middle. Big deal.
Something made that noise we heard.
It must’ve come from another room. Come on, we’re wasting our time here.
Another room? We saw the door close. We ought to at least have a poke about under these leaves. Pass me that net, would you?
(SCATHINGLY) You honestly think there’s something hiding in the water?
It’s possible. Besides, we don’t know for certain that there’s any water in there, do we?
(FX: SHE POKES AT THE LEAFY SURFACE OF THE POOL. THE POLE
THROUGH INTO WATER)
Okay, so there is water in there. (FX: SHE RAISES THE POLE. WATER AND SLIME DRIPS FROM IT, ON TO THE LAYER OF LEAVES) Ugh. Pretty rank. Look at all that slime.
(ANXIOUSLY) Nothing could survive under there. Let’s go.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 23
You know what’s weird?
What?
Where are the leaves from? I mean, if this was an outdoor pool it would make sense. But this room is sealed up tight. There isn’t even a door leading onto a terrace.
Does it matter?
It might.
Look, nothing makes sense here. We’ve already established that. Let’s just go.
(SIGHS) Okay. I suppose you’re right that no-one could hide under there. Not for as long as we’ve been in the room anyway.
(FX: A SUDDEN DOUBLE-SPLASH, AS OF SOMETHING BRIEFLY BREAKING THE SURFACE BEFORE SUBMERGING AGAIN)
What was that?
(RISING ANXIETY) Nothing.
It was definitely something.
Just an air bubble. Come on. (FX: SHE STOMPS AWAY)
(SCEPTICAL) An air bubble? (FOLLOWING) Hey, hang about —
FX: FADE
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 24
12. INT. MAIN HALLWAY
FX: THE CLOCK STRIKES SIX
13. INT. CORRIDOR
FX: FADE UP. GIRLS WALKING TO STOP
Which way now, d’you think?
I think this place is... strange. Corridors leading on and on, twisting round and around [and —]
(SEES SOMETHING) That wasn’t here.
What?
Words, on the wall — see? They weren’t here when we went into the pool room.
You’re sure-?
(READING) ‘You Are Mine’. (POINTING) Same there. And there. On the ceiling, even.
FX: CAUTIOUS FOOTSTEPS AS RACHEL CROSSES TO THE WALL
(QUIETLY) Whoever it was did this, they didn’t write it.
What do you mean?
These words have been burned into the plaster.
Burned? How?
I don’t know. With a blowtorch, [maybe?]
(FX: INTERRUPTED BY A LOUD BANG FROM DOWN CORRIDOR — OPEN
BANGING AGAINST FRAME)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 25
RACHEL/ SALLY
CRY OUT, STARTLED
(BARK OF LAUGHTER) It’s okay. It’s just the window down the end there, look.
FX: FOOTSTEPS AS THEY HURRY DOWN CORRIDOR
(WALKING) Perhaps whoever did all this —
(WALKING) Climbed in and out of the window? (STOPPING) We’re four flights up now —
(EXCLAMATION, LOOKING OUT OF WINDOW) Hey! Then who’s that?
What?
Some bloke. On the path there.
FX: RACHEL BANGS ON THE WINDOW
Oi! You down there! (BEAT) No use, he’s gone. Disappeared round the side of the house. Did you get a proper look at him?
Only for a second. Dark jacket. White hat. Didn’t look like
Soames.
Come on. Let’s check it out.
FX: FOOTSTEPS DOWN STAIRS. FADE
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 26
14. EXT. GROUNDS
(FX: FADE UP. WIND; SCRAPE AND RUSTLE OF FOLIAGE. THE CLUNK OF A LATCH AND A CREAK AS THE MAIN DOOR OPENS)
It’s freezing out here.
Come on!
(FX: CRACKLING, RAPID FOOTSTEPS AS THEY HURRY ALONG THE
PATH THAT SNAKES AROUND THE HOUSE. EVENTUALLY
SLOW, STOP)
(PANTING) I think this is where we saw him. Yeah, there’s the window of the room we were in.
(PANTING) You’re sure?
Pretty sure. It’s one of that row anyway. I recognise this tree.
This place might be run-down, but it’s huge. I wish I knew where we were.
Maybe there’s a library or something inside, with books on the local area.
Maybe. (PAUSE) Well, there’s no sign of our mysterious man. Maybe he went back into the hotel.
Or he could’ve gone to ground. For all we know, he might be watching us right now.
Comforting thought. Shall we head back?
Let’s walk all the way round. We might learn something.
(FX: THEIR FOOTSTEPS RESUME; MORE LEISURELY NOW. OFF/HIGH ABOVE — A SUDDEN LOUD CRACKLING FLASH, LIKE A FIERY BURST OF
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 27
Did you see that?
I saw something. Lightning?
No, it came from inside.
Inside?
Up there. Top of that turret. Huge flash of blue light at the window.
An explosion maybe?
No, it was more like... oh, I dunno... a camera flash or something.
Hell of a camera.
Well, maybe it was a telly blowing up.
No electricity, remember.
(EXASPERATED SIGH) All right, Miss Smartypants. What do you think it was?
(HALF-JOKINGLY) Maybe there is a mad scientist up there.
(HESITANTLY) I think... No, it don’t matter.
What?
When the light flashed, I saw something else. At the window. A figure.
A person, you mean?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 28
Maybe.
Well... was it or wasn’t it?
I dunno. There was something weird about it.
In what way?

It was only in silhouette. Back-lit, so maybe I didn’t see it clearly. But it looked.. too tall for a normal person. And too thin. And its hands and head looked long and narrow, as if they’d been stretched. (SNORTS A NERVOUS LAUGH) Like I say, I didn’t get a proper look.
Did it seem male or female?
Male maybe? The head looked smooth. Bald.
PAUSE AS THEY TAKE THIS IN
(DECISIVELY) Come on. Let’s find the nearest door and go back
inside.
FX: FADE OUT FOOTSTEPS ON GRIT
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 29
15. INT. KITCHEN
FX: CLUNK OF AN OPENING DOOR. POT BUBBLING GENTLY ON STOVE
Something smells good.
Mr Soames did say that dinner was at seven. This must be it.
(FX: FOOTSTEPS ON TILED FLOOR AS RACHEL CROSSES THE ROOM. SCRAPE OF A METAL BUCKET ON A WOODEN TABLE AS SHE DRAGS IT CLOSER AND TILTS IT. FISH GUTS SLOP HEAVILY INSIDE)
Judging by this bucketful of guts, we’re having fish.
(RUEFULLY) Yum.
So what’s in the pot? Severed head? Pet rabbit?
(FX: FOOTSTEPS ON TILES AS SALLY CROSSES TO THE COOKER. FADE UP SOUND OF BUBBLING POT)
Potatoes. (FX: OFF — THE ‘ZING’ OF STEEL ON STEEL AS RACHEL EXTRACTS A KNIFE FROM A METAL RACK ON THE WALL) Hey, what are you doing?
Taking one of these knives.
What for?
Defend myself with.
Defend yourself against what?
Who knows? That thing in the tower room maybe.
(LAUGHS) You’re paranoid, you know that?
Take my advice, darling. Always be prepared.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 30
But you can’t just go round stealing things.
Who’s gonna know? Hardly a case of too many cooks in here, is
af wis
(FX: A BELL TINKLES, ONE OF A ROW OF SMALL SERVANTS’ BELLS ON THE WALL)
(SNIGGERS) You rang m’lud?
Come on, let’s scarper before we’re rumbled. See if we can find
this tower.
(FX: FOOTSTEPS ON TILES AS THEY CROSS TO THE INTERNAL DOOR. AFTER A FEW STEPS THE BELL TINKLES AGAIN)
Someone’s impatient.
FX: THE TINKLING BELL CONTINUES AND IS JOINED BY ANOTHER
Very impatient. I wonder if-
(FX: SUDDENLY ALL THE BELLS START RINGING AT ONCE, A HIDEOUS CACOPHONY, DROWNING OUT HER WORDS)
(SHOUTING) What the hell’s this? Fire drill?
(SHOUTING) Let’s get out before they drive us mad.
FX: CROSSFADE FROM CACOPHONY OF BELLS TO:
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 31
16. INT. UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR
FX: WELL OFF, DOWNSTAIRS CLOCK STRIKES ONCE FOR HALF-HOUR
(TRUDGING TO HALT) Listen. Half-six.
Soon be dinner time.
(SUDDEN FRUSTRATION) Oh, this is insane! How can that tower not exist?
It does exist. We know it exists because we’ve seen it.
But we've looked everywhere. I’m sick of the sight of corridors and staircases.
There must be a route we haven’t discovered yet, that’s all. We just have to be methodical.
Easier said than done. This place is a maze. We’re like rats chasing our tails.
(RELUCTANTLY) Maybe...
Maybe what?
I hate to say this, but maybe the tower’s only accessible via the lift.
You want to try it?
Do you?
I’m game if you are.
From what I remember, it’s back this way. (FX: THEY EXIT. FADE)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 32

SALLY: Oh.

SALLY: You see?
RACHEL: Damn thing. It’s like it knows what we’re up to. It’s like the whole house knows, and it’s working against us. Playing with us.
SALLY: You’re being paranoid.
RACHEL: Oh, am I?
SALLY: Well, listen to yourself. You’re suggesting that the house is somehow... alive. Intelligent.
RACHEL: All right, well maybe it’s not the house then. But someone somewhere is watching us. Manipulating us. Take it from me, darling, someone means us harm.
SALLY: You’re such a pessimist.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 33
RACHEL: No, I’m a realist. You should try it sometime.
RACHEL: (FX: OFF/DISTANT — FIST BANGING ON WOOD; CLANG OF THE FRONT
DOOR: BELL)
SALLY: Someone’s arrived.
RACHEL: (NON-PLUSSED) Whoopee. Hope they’ve brought a bottle. We can have a party.

RACHEL: (MUTTERS) Yeah, let’s.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 34
SOAMES: (TO TOBY, BEING MENACED) I already told you, gentlemen — the Master will explain [everything] —
TOBY: Everything, yeah. Only I don’t feel like waiting. Cough up, you ghastly old retainer!

SALLY: (FX: FROM OFF, DESCENDING STAIRS) Hey! You two! No need for the rough stuff!
TOBY: (FLIRTING) Well, hello there, gorgeous. And who might you be?
SALLY: (FX: STEPPING OFF STAIRS, WALKING FORWARD) No idea. Number 18?

JEROME: Hi.

BEHIND: SALLY)
RACHEL: Do you two know each other?

RACHEL: Just answer the question, pal.

19. INT. BLUEFIRE HOUSE. MAIN HALLWAY (CONTINUED
A doctor? You’re a medical man?
Not exclusively.
A shrink, then? Is this some sort of nut house?
Very astute. But no. You’re not mad, if that’s what you think.
We were told to expect the Master at seven.
(ALARMED) The Master?
The Master of the house. Mr Soames said he’d tell us what was going on.
Ah. In that case, that would be me.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 39
You own this place?
Not strictly, no.
What are you then? The caretaker?

Let’s just say that this is a controlled environment, one which we can all understand. (RAISES VOICE, TAKING CHARGE) I suggest we all convene in the dining room. If you wouldn’t mind unhanding Mr Soames, I’m sure he’1ll serve us an excellent dinner.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 40
20. INT. DINING ROOM
(FX: FADE UP CLATTER OF SERVING TROLLEY AS SOAMES PUSHES IT ROUND THE TABLE, SERVING SOUP. HE HALTS BESIDE THE DOCTOR)
Soup, sir?
Thank you, Mr Soames. Mulligatawny, isn’t it?
(FX: LADLING SOUP) Yes, sir.
FX: SOAMES EXITS THROUGH:
(SLURPING HIS SOUP) Splendid. Reminds me of a little place in the Khyber Pass —
(INTERRUPTING) Never mind that. We’ve been waiting long enough. Tell us what we need to know.
(FIRMLY) Aquaphobia.
What?
The morbid fear of water. Isn’t that your particular bugbear, Ms 5?
What if it is? What’s that got to do with anything?
And you, Mr 12. A rather exotic fear of mirrors, correct?
(WARILY) ‘Catoptrophobia’, they call it. Fantastic fact.
And you, Mr 16...?
Mine’s cockroaches. I don’t know the word for it. I’ve had a thing about them since I was a kid.
So we’re all phobic about something. Who isn’t?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 41
Hang on, darling. What’s your particular Achilles Heel? Just to get the full set, you understand?
I have athazagoraphobia. It’s the fear of being forgotten or ignored. And please don’t call me ‘darling’.
And what about you, Dr whatever-your-name-is? What gives you the heebie-jeebies?
Oh, the universe is full of terrors, Mr 12. You couldn’t begin to imagine...
So that’s why we’re here, is it? Because we’re all phobic?
In a way. (SLURPING) This really is excellent soup.
See? I was right. This is an experiment.
Is that true, Doctor? Are you here to experiment on us? Or to cure us?
Neither. I’m here to rescue you.
Rescue us?
It’s what I do. (SLURPS)
(LAUGHS) No disrespect, old man, but 16 and I are not exactly damsels-in-distress. So if the ladies here need protecting -
I can take care of myself, thanks. I don’t need some knuckle- head looking out for me.
(AMUSED) Well, it’s a step up from ‘moron’, I suppose.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 42
Shut up, you two. I want to hear what the Doctor has to say. What do we need rescuing from, Doctor?
That’s a very good question.
And are you going to give us a very good answer?
In time. The important thing now is that you stick together, refuse to give in to your fears.
Are you suggesting we’re about to come under attack? Because if so, I'd appreciate knowing what we’re up against. Forewarned is forearmed.
Not in this case, believe me.
Well, that’s just it, old man. Why should we believe you?
And why not just tell us? Don’t you think we can handle the truth?
That’s not it.
(FRUSTRATED) So what is, Doctor? What’s so terrible that we’re better off not knowing about it?
Isn’t it obvious what he’s doing? He’s on some sort of power yo ag oe
It’s a question of power, certainly. But not mine.
Stop talking in riddles. What does that mean?
All I can tell you is that something ancient and foul has emerged from the wilderness and drawn you to this house. And that speaking of it will only strengthen it.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 43
What do you mean, ‘drawn’ us here?
I’ve said too much already. You’1ll just have to trust me for now.
Why should we do that?
Because I’m the only one who can help you.
And what’s to stop us walking out of here right now?
There’s nowhere to go.
We'll see about that. (FX: SCRAPE OF CHAIR AS SHE STANDS UP) Who’s with me?
FX: SCRAPE OF CHAIR
Count me in, sweetheart.
Why don’t you humans ever listen?
‘You humans’? So what are you? A super hero?
It’s imperative that you stay together.
We will — as long as we’re all going in the same direction. You two coming?
No, I’m staying here.
Don’t tell me you believe this weirdo?
I don’t know. But we’ve seen and heard plenty here we can’t explain.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 44
Magic tricks. I can’t believe you’re so gullible.
What about you, soldier?
Why d’you call me that?
Just a turn of phrase. You coming or not?
No. I think I’1ll stay here too.
Please yourselves. Well? Not going to try and stop us, Doctor?
Your minds are clearly made up.
You got that right. Well... see you around. Or not.
Yes, cheerio. Have fun.
(FX: THEY MOVE AWAY; OPEN THE MAIN DOOR WITH A CREAK; BANG IT
BEHIND THEM)
What will they find out there, Doctor?
Disappointment. Confusion. Fear.
Will they be okay?
FX: CLOCK BONGS ONCE FOR HALF-SEVEN, OFF
Finish your soup. It’s getting cold.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 45
21. EXT. GROUNDS
(FX: WIND; RUSTLE OF FOLIAGE; FOOTSTEPS TRUDGING THROUGH
(WALKING) What say we find a nice country pub and get to know one another properly?
(WALKING) How can we do that when we have no idea who we are?
(WALKING) Well, that’s my point, sweetheart. A good chat to jog the old brainbox, grease the cogs as it were...
FX: RACHEL’S FOOTSTEPS STOP ABRUPTLY, THEN TOBY’S
Something the matter?
Call me ‘sweetheart’ one more time, and I’1l1 swing for you.
WALKS
Duly noted. (WALKS) So what shall I call you? ‘5’?
(WALKING) Don’t call me anything.
(WALKING) Bit unfriendly.
(STOPS) I’m not interested in making friends. I just want to get out of here and find out who I am.
(STOPPED) Me too. But there’s nothing to stop us being civil. We are in the same boat, after all.
We might be deadly enemies in real life.
Or husband and wife. Have you thought about that?
God forbid.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 46
Oh, thanks a bunch. (PAUSE) Look, I meant what I said... about talking, I mean.
(SIGH) Okay then — talk.
All right. Where to start?
Tell me about your phobia. Mirrors, isn’t it?
Yes.
What is it about them that frightens you?
Well... I know it sounds loopy, but I’ve always had this idea that if I look into a mirror I’1ll see someone else looking back at me. Someone who isn’t me, I mean. Either that, ovr...
Or?
. or that I’1l see something standing behind me. Something terrible.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 47
22. INT. DINING ROOM
(FX: TICKING OF GRANDFATHER CLOCK; SCRAPE AND CLATTER OF CUTLERY /CROCKERY )
Beef or trout, sir?
Trout, I think, Mr Soames. Stimulates the brain cells.
(FX: ‘TINK’ OF SERVING TONGS AGAINST CHINA AS SOAMES TRANSFERS A PORTION OF FISH FROM PLATTER TO PLATE)
And for you, miss?
(DISTRACTED) Er... yes, I’1l have the trout too. Look, what is this, Doctor?
FX: SOAMES SERVING SALLY THROUGH:
It smells like a ginger and rosemary sauce, unless I’m much mistaken.
I don’t mean the food. I mean why are we just sitting here? Having dinner?
Aren’t you hungry?
(TO SOAMES) Beef, mate. Cheers.
Sir. (FX: SERVING THROUGH: )

That’s beside the point! You talked about something ancient and foul coming out of the wilderness. You intimated we were about to come under attack. Shouldn’t we be doing something? Trying to escape like the others?
A pointless exercise. (BEGINS EATING) Eat, eat!
FX: SIMULTANEOUSLY, SOAMES DEPARTS, WHEELING TROLLEY
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 48
I don’t get it. You said you were here to rescue us.
(MOUTH FULL) And so I am.

What kind of door?
I’1l know it when I see it.

Of course I know what I’m doing! (PAUSE) I’m just not entirely sure what I’1l be doing five minutes from now. If there’s one thing I’ve learned, it’s that it pays to be flexible.
So this foul and ancient thing? Is it on its way?
It’s already here.
(NERVOUSLY) Really?
Where is it?
In the shadows. Biding its time.

Because I’m here. And it doesn’t know what I am. Yet.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 49
23. EXT. GROUNDS
FX: WIND; RUSTLE OF FOLIAGE
What about you? Your fear of water?
It’s something I’ve learned to live with.
So it’s drowning you’re afraid of?

It wouldn’t be a phobia if it was that simple. (PAUSE) Water makes me anxious. It’s like a predator without a face, a killer without mercy. I hate the way it moves. It’s... muscular. Sinewy. It just keeps going, no matter what.
It’s running water you don’t like, then?
No. Its stillness bothers me too. It’s like it’s waiting. The fact that you can’t see beneath the surface — as if it’s hiding something.
Keeping clean must be tricky.
(SNAPS) Are you making fun of me?
Absolutely not. You’re looking at a man who can’t shave without getting the sweats, remember.
(SUBDUED LAUGH) I can manage showers. But not baths — and definitely not swimming pools. Under the water it’s another world. Heavy and airless and dark. I get breathless just talking about it...
Best not then. Let’s change the subject.
But it makes me angry. It’s irrational, stupid. Besides, this is what we should be talking about. It’s the only thing that
defines us here. How long have you had your fear of mirrors?
Where does it come from?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 50
No idea.
Have you ever seen anything in a mirror? Anything that frightened you?
(ANXIOUS) I’m not sure... I can’t remember.
(FX: OFF/DISTANT, LOUD RUSTLE OF WIND THROUGH THE TREES — BUT
DISTORTED... MORE LIKE A BRIEF, ROARING GUSH OF WATER)
What was that?
Just the wind.
You sure?
Yes. What did you think it was?
Nothing. I didn’t think it was anything... (RELUCTANTLY) It sounded like water. Just for a second. (NERVOUS LAUGH) This place must be getting to me.
How far have we come, do you think?
Dunno. A mile? These bushes and trees are so thick it’s difficult to judge.
(FX: SUDDEN HIGH-PITCHED STING OF MUSIC, A FLASH OF SOUND, ZINGY AND METALLIC — SOMETHING TO MAKE THE LISTENERS JUMP)
(GASP) Did you see that?
What?
Something in the trees, just there. A flash of movement.
A person, you mean?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 51
I’m not sure. It looked... silvery. Formless but fast. It seemed to reflect the light.
(SPOOKED) Like water?
(ALSO SPOOKED) Or glass...
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 52
24. INT. DINING ROOM
(FX: TICKING OF GRANDFATHER CLOCK; SCRAPE AND CLATTER OF CUTLERY/CROCKERY AS THEY EAT)
What are you, Doctor?
To our friend? A juicy morsel. Not unlike this last piece of fish. (SWALLOWS) Delicious. (FX: SETS CUTLERY ON PLATE) Thank you, Soames.
(WALKING FORWARD) Sir.
You’re saying you’re, I don’t know, bait?
More of a distraction. A glittering trinket to catch the eye.
So you’re hoping to get this thing’s attention while we [slip out the back door, as it were?]
(TO JEROME) Finished, sir?
(DISTRACTED) What? Oh... yeah.
In that case, I’1ll take your plate, if I may?
Go for it.
(FX: SOAMES PICKS UP THE PLATE — AND A COCKROACH EMERGES FROM
RAPID, CLICKING, SCUTTLING LEGS. JEROME LEAPS OUT
SCRAPE/SQUEAL OF CHAIR LEGS SCUDDING ACROSS THE FLOOR; CRASH AS THE CHAIR FALLS OVER)
(SHOCK AND DISGUST) Oh, no-! No, no, no!
What’s the matter?
(FREAKED) Didn’t you see that? Didn’t any of you see that
thing?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 53
I’m afraid I saw nothing, sir.
You must have done! It was this big. It ran right across the table and over the side. (SHUDDER OF REVULSION)
What did? What was it?
A cockroach. A great big cockroach.
It’s started.
What has? The attack, you mean?
Yes. What you saw wasn’t real, Mr 16.
It so was.
It might look real. It might even feel real. But it’s a manifestation of your fear, lifted directly from your mind. You must fight it. Deny it. (FX: SCRAPE OF CHAIR AS THE DOCTOR STANDS) Stay here.
Where are you going?
Our enemy has come out into the open. That makes it vulnerable.
FX: FOOTSTEPS MOVING RAPIDLY AWAY
Yes, but where are you going, Doctor?
Hunting!
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 54
25. EXT. GROUNDS/MAZE
(FX: RUSTLE OF FOLIAGE; SNAP AND CRACKLE OF BRANCHES THROUGH SCENE AS RACHEL AND TOBY STRUGGLE TO MAKE HEADWAY )
(PRICKED) Ow! These thorns. They’re lethal.
Let’s hope not. (GRUNTS AS HE TRIES TO HACK A WAY THROUGH) It would help if we could find some open ground. But it’s all so wild.

Just tangles of brambles and nettles and dead trees. No walls or fields, no sound of traffic... What was it that Doctor said? That there was nowhere to go? Maybe he meant it literally. Maybe we’re dead and this is limbo...
And that little Doctor chap is the Devil Incarnate, eh?
Who knows?
(FX: OFF/HIGH UP, THE BRIEF RUSHING, WAVE-LIKE SOUND AGAIN; LOUD AND SUDDEN, WITH A SENSE OF MOVEMENT, OF FLOWING FROM ONE SET OF TREES TO ANOTHER)
That sound again. It came from behind us.
Just wind in the treetops.
So how come the treetops aren’t moving?
EERIE SILENCE
It comes and goes. Nothing odd about that. Shall we press on or look for another route?
(SIGHS) I don’t think we’ll get through here. What time is it, do you reckon?
Haven’t a clue.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 55

elements.text: PART THREE
(FX: HURRYING ACROSS) Doctor? Doctor, can you hear me?
(SUDDENLY SNAPPING TO) Yes. (SITTING UP) Where am I?
Don’t get up. You’re in the medical wing of the Fulton Down military base.
Fulton Down. Yes, yes, I remember now.
(UNCERTAINLY) Doctor, are you all right?
(QUIETLY; DOOM-LADEN) Dr Soames. I seem to have made a terrible mistake.

38. INT. MEDICAL WING (CONTINUED
(HESITANTLY) A mistake? What do you mean?
How long was I out?
Ninety minutes? But you began to convulse ten minutes ago.
Your readings went through the roof. We thought we’d lost you.
We severed your link with the system and transferred you to here — whereupon you began to stabilise quickly, thank goodness.
(URGENT) The test subjects. How are they?
Fine. Still under sedation.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 77
I need to see them urgently.
(FX: CREAK OF BEDSPRINGS AS HE SITS UP AND TRIES TO GET OUT OF BED, STILL ATTACHED TO VARIOUS MONITORS — CLATTERS AND SCRAPES AS HE HALF-DRAGS THEM WITH HIM)
Careful, Doctor. You’re still attached to the monitors. Let me help you.
(FX: PEELING/POPPING SOUNDS AS SHE REMOVES SUCTION PADS FROM
You still haven’t explained what you meant by ‘mistake’.
No time now. But the base must be evacuated.
I’m not sure if I-
Immediately, Dr Soames. We need a priority red evacuation. All personnel, aside from myself and the test subjects, must leave.
I’1ll do it, Doctor. But this is my project. I’m staying too.
And me.
No. It’s too dangerous.
Dr Soames and I are the only people who fully understand the Bluefire system, Doctor. You need us here.
(RELUCTANTLY) Oh, very well.
I’1l make that call on the way to the Isolation Ward. (EXITING) This way, Doctor. Come along, Miss Pritchard.
FX: FADE AS ALL HURRY OUT
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 78
39. INT. ISOLATION WARD
(FX: IN B/G, DISTANT, WE HEAR THE EVACUATION ALARM, AND THUNDERING OF SQUADDIES’ FEET ON THE WAY OUT. BRING UP CALM BLIPS AND BEEPS OF MONITORS, CLOSE TO)
You see, Doctor? All sleeping peacefully.
Nevertheless, they’re vulnerable in this state. How long will it take to revive them?
Not long. But I’d advise against it. You’ve read the report of what happens when they’re conscious?
Yes, yes. The subjects show evidence of increased psychic activity.
More than that, Doctor. The subjects have been unable to break the psychic link to the Bluefire system. As a result they become distressed, resulting in -
(INTERRUPTING) .. destructive psychic manifestations. I know.
To put it bluntly, Doctor, things fly about. The subjects become uncontrollable.
Awake, they’re a danger to themselves and to us, Doctor.
They’re far more dangerous asleep, believe me.
How so?
Let me ask you a question, Dr Soames. If you were at home, with all your doors and windows open, and you heard that an escaped tiger was prowling the area, what would you do?
I’d close all the doors and windows.
Precisely.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 79
I don’t follow.
I think I do. You’re saying that the unconscious minds of the test subjects are wide open to attack?
Yes.
Attack from what?
First things first. Let’s shut out the tiger.
All right. Miss Pritchard, we’ll start with Private Morgan. 200 micrograms of naloxone, I think.
Dr Soames. (FX: PICKS UP SYRINGE, DRAWS UP INJECTION)
I hope you know what you’re doing, Doctor.
So do I.
INJECTED — MOANS SOFTLY
There. We should see the effect within a minute or so.
Would you like all four test subjects revived simultaneously, Doctor?
No. I’1l stabilise Sally first. It shouldn’t take long.
You'll stabilise her? And how on Earth will you do that?
I have an excellent bedside manner.
FX: EVACUATION ALARM ABRUPTLY CEASES
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 80
The alarms have stopped.
Then we can assume the evacuation is complete.
(STIRS) Can’t stop me...
Private Morgan. Sally. Can you hear me?
(GROGGY) Help me. It’s coming. (GASPS; AWAKE) It’s here...!
(GENTLY) No. Listen to me, Sally Morgan. I am the Doctor and you are safe.
(BREATHLESS, CONFUSED) Safe?
Yes.
(FX: A GUST OF ETHEREAL ‘WIND’. A METAL DISH CONTAINING
FLIPS OFF THE TABLE AND FALLS WITH A CRASH)
Watch out! It’s happening again —
I told you, Doctor, things fly about! Chair-!
(FX: A CHAIR FLIES ACROSS THE ROOM AND SMASHES INTO A WALL; THE
GLASS OF THE OBSERVATION WINDOW CRACKS; A DRIP STAND FALLS WITH A CLATTER OF METAL)
(CALM) Sally Morgan. I am the Doctor and you are safe.
FX: ‘WIND’ ABRUPTLY STOPS. SILENCE
(AMAZED) What did you do?
I set up a psychological block in Sally’s brain. In short, I cut off our enemy’s food supply.
But... you just touched her temples.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 81
There’s a knack. (GENTLY) How are you feeling now, Sally?
(CAUTIOUSLY) Better. My mind feels... clear.
I’ve closed a door, that’s all. You’re safe for now, but the tiger’s still prowling.
What did you mean, ‘food supply’?
Our friend has been stimulating Sally’s limbic system and feeding off the resultant emotions.
And who or what is this ‘enemy’, Doctor?
All in good time. Let’s close the rest of these doors first.
FX: FADE

(FX: FADE UP. THE REVIVED TEST SUBJECTS ARE SITTING UP,

/ TOBY / JEROME

Yes, Sir. Sorry; sir.
Now I’m going to need to run a few cognitive tests, so if [you’1ll-]
(INTERRUPTING) There’s no time for that, Dr Soames.
I’m sorry, but it’s procedure, Doctor.
(INTERRUPTING AGAIN) Procedure is just another word for procrastination. (SUDDENLY AUTHORITATIVE) You, soldier, full name and rank!
(SNAPS TO ATTENTION) Private Jerome Fisher, sir.

Private Toby Dodds, sir!
And I’m Private Sally Morgan.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 83
There, you see, Dr Soames? The mental faculties of your test subjects are unimpared.
Your assessment criteria are hardly scientific, Doctor.
I tend to find that cutting a few corners invariably results in a more interesting journey.
This is highly irresponsible! We have no idea of the manner or extent of the psychological trauma that may have resulted from the subjects’ exposure to the system.
And that’s your primary concern, is it? The welfare of your test subjects?
(WARILY) Of course.
How philanthropic of you. And here’s me thinking you might be more concerned about the fate of your ‘experiment’.
That’s unfair, Doctor. Dr Soames has put a huge amount of work into this project. The prior research was exhaustive, the safety procedures rigorously checked and re-checked.
There was no indication whatsoever that Bluefire would have a detrimental psychological effect on its subjects. In fact, such an outcome was deemed impossible.
(COLDLY) And yet it happened. Miss Morgan? Sally?
Yes, Doctor?
What were you told about the Bluefire Project before you volunteered for it?
We didn’t withhold information, if that’s what you’re insinuating.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 84
I should like to hear what Sally has to say.
(HESITANTLY) They asked for army volunteers with specific phobias. We were told that the object of the research was to identify and isolate those phobias, so they might be.. I don’t know, extracted?
Except that instead of creating fearless warriors, Bluefire caused psychic instability. So much so that the test subjects’ destructive urges could only be curtailed by heavy sedation.
There were twenty-four volunteers in all, Doctor. Twenty completed the process with no ill-effects whatsoever.
(COLDLY) Those odds were still unacceptable.
We’re trying to isolate and eradicate fear here, Doctor. Isn’t that a worthwhile pursuit?
Not if the sole purpose is to create more efficient killers.
The purpose is to prevent young people like these succumbing to a potentially debilitating emotion. One which, in battle, might prove to be the difference between life and death.
Hasn’t it ever occurred to you, Dr Soames, that fear can be a positive emotion? Take away fear and people lose their sense of self-preservation.
If that’s true, then it can be countered through training, discipline.
So you still maintain that your intentions are philanthropic?
To a large extent, yes.
And does that include your research into the application of R.E.P. technology?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 85
R. E. what?
(FX: PULLING CURTAINS FROM AROUND A BED) Doctor — a word in
private, if you would?

FX: SOAMES PULLS CURTAIN RAIL

(SOTTO) That phrase was not of my choosing.

(SOTTO) That is a gross over-simplification —

. I’m concerned that we have more important matters to attend to.

come along.

What sort of questions, Doctor?
Well, for example: what do you four remember about your time in
the system?
Not a lot.
Bad dreams mostly.
I remember a house. A big old house. There was Jerome, Rachel, Toby and me. You were there, Doctor. And you too, Dr Soames.
(SURPRISED) Me?

(FX: A SERIES OF QUICK CUTS FROM PARTS ONE/TWO, ALL WITH
[FROM SCENE 8: ] I have this fear that one day I’ll wake up and no-one will be able to see or hear me. I’ll just be... gone.
[FROM SCENE 21: ]

47. INT. BLUEFIRE SYSTEM OPERATIONS ROOM
But what is it, this ‘Mi’en Kalarash’?
A legend. A scary bedtime story. In the ancient mythology of my people there are tales of an entity that inhabits the wastelands between realities, feeding on nightmares.
And you reckon that’s what’s got inside our heads?
It has infiltrated your minds through the Bluefire system, yes.
How?
I don’t know.
But this is mental. I mean — time machines, aliens, evil entities! Are you for real?

Shush, Rachel. (ADDRESSING THE DOCTOR) She has got a point, though, Doctor. Even accepting what we’ve seen, this does seem pretty... far-fetched. What makes you think this ‘entity’ has got into the Bluefire system?
Where I come from there is an ancient language known as Old High Gallifeyan. And in Old High Gallifreyan, ‘Mi’en Kalarash’ translates as ‘Blue Fire’.
PAUSE
Sorry, but it still sounds loopy to me.
Loopy or not, it looks like we’re stuck with it. So what happens next?
I re-route the Bluefire system into the TARDIS and connect it to the Vortex Manipulator.
Does that actually mean anything?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 97
(SIGHS) It means I’m constructing a temporal trap. If I can capture and contain the Kalarash, I can use my TARDIS to send it back into the wastelands.
And will that work?
It has to. I thought that I could enter the Bluefire system, rescue the four of you and find a way to banish the Kalarash from there.
But...?
But, it anticipated my every move. Outmanoeuvred me.
Meaning what?
Meaning that it hitched a lift back with me into the physical world. This world.
So it’s in your head now?
No, no. It jumped ship as soon as I started to regain consciousness.
So where is it?
Lying low. Acclimatising. Ideally I need to draw it into the open while it’s still disorientated.
But how come it needed you, Doctor? Why didn’t it just use our minds to get here?
Because to climb out of a hole you need rope, not thread.
What?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 98
I think he means that our minds are puny compared to his.
Oh, charming.
No offence. In my case, it’s simply a question of advanced evolution.
And that’s supposed to make us feel better?
It might do, given that it’s my fault the Kalarash is here.
How come?
At some point in the past it must have detected my presence, picked up my temporal trace. Since then it’s been devising a way to reach me.
So what does it want, Doctor? Now it’s free?
Given the materials it has to hand, I’d say it’s seeking to manipulate and corrupt impressionable military minds in order to bring about Armageddon.
Are you serious?
No, Mr Dodds, I’m joking. I always joke about the end of the world.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 99

FX: FADE UP
(FX: FLICKING LEVERS. THRUM OF POWER) There, that should do it.
Should? Aren’t you sure?

Rest assured, Dr Soames, if this doesn’t work it’s not something you’ll have to worry about. Let’s see how the others are getting on. (WALKING) Come on.

. Oh, Doctor! I presume these cables will accommodate the power linkage between the Bluefire system and your machine?

(FX: WALKING OVER TO SPOT) With any luck the Kalarash will manifest right about... (STOPPING) .. here.

(CALLING) Everybody, gather round again.
(FX: AS HE AND OTHERS GATHER ROUND DOCTOR) Aye-aye, looks like it’s showtime.
Now. The entity is currently composed of a series of slivers in incremental time. I’ve constructed a kind of time magnet, designed to draw it out into the open.
(INCREDULOUSLY) Incremental time?

Like a vast number of microscopic iron filings stuck between the time-cracks. When I switch on, temporal energy from the
will drag all those filings down to this one fixed point
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 101
. and, hey presto!, our friend will appear?
Precisely.
Will it be like that thing I saw in the attic room, Doctor?
Possibly.
What thing?
Tall and thin. Like a reflection in a fun house mirror. Dark- skinned, sort of leathery. Its face was... vicious. Animal-like. And it was surrounded by blue fire. Bathed in it.

SALLY: But what is it, this ‘Mi’en Kalarash’?
DOCTOR: A legend. A scary bedtime story. In the ancient mythology of my people there are tales of an entity that inhabits the wastelands between realities, feeding on nightmares.
JEROME: And you reckon that’s what’s got inside our heads?
DOCTOR: It has infiltrated your minds through the Bluefire system, yes.
JEROME: How?
DOCTOR: I don’t know.
RACHEL: But this is mental. I mean — time machines, aliens, evil entities! Are you for real?
SALLY: Shush, Rachel. (ADDRESSING THE DOCTOR) She has got a point, though, Doctor. Even accepting what we’ve seen, this does seem pretty... far-fetched. What makes you think this ‘entity’ has got into the Bluefire system?
DOCTOR: Where I come from there is an ancient language known as Old High Gallifeyan. And in Old High Gallifreyan, ‘Mi’en Kalarash’ translates as ‘Blue Fire’.
TOBY: Sorry, but it still sounds loopy to me.
RACHEL: Loopy or not, it looks like we’re stuck with it. So what happens next?
DOCTOR: I re-route the Bluefire system into the TARDIS and connect it to the Vortex Manipulator.
RACHEL: Does that actually mean anything?
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 97
DOCTOR: (SIGHS) It means I’m constructing a temporal trap. If I can capture and contain the Kalarash, I can use my TARDIS to send it back into the wastelands.
SALLY: And will that work?
DOCTOR: It has to. I thought that I could enter the Bluefire system, rescue the four of you and find a way to banish the Kalarash from there.
EVE: But...?
DOCTOR: But, it anticipated my every move. Outmanoeuvred me.
TOBY: Meaning what?
DOCTOR: Meaning that it hitched a lift back with me into the physical world. This world.
RACHEL: So it’s in your head now?
DOCTOR: No, no. It jumped ship as soon as I started to regain consciousness.
SOAMES: So where is it?
DOCTOR: Lying low. Acclimatising. Ideally I need to draw it into the open while it’s still disorientated.
JEROME: But how come it needed you, Doctor? Why didn’t it just use our minds to get here?
DOCTOR: Because to climb out of a hole you need rope, not thread.
JEROME: What?
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 98
SALLY: I think he means that our minds are puny compared to his.
TOBY: Oh, charming.
DOCTOR: No offence. In my case, it’s simply a question of advanced evolution.
RACHEL: And that’s supposed to make us feel better?
DOCTOR: It might do, given that it’s my fault the Kalarash is here.
SALLY: How come?
DOCTOR: At some point in the past it must have detected my presence, picked up my temporal trace. Since then it’s been devising a way to reach me.
EVE: So what does it want, Doctor? Now it’s free?
DOCTOR: Given the materials it has to hand, I’d say it’s seeking to manipulate and corrupt impressionable military minds in order to bring about Armageddon.
TOBY: Are you serious?
DOCTOR: No, Mr Dodds, I’m joking. I always joke about the end of the world.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 99
DOCTOR: (FX: FLICKING LEVERS. THRUM OF POWER) There, that should do it.
RACHEL: Should? Aren’t you sure?
DOCTOR: It’s a bit of a lash-up. Square pegs in round holes. Best I can do, in the circumstances.
SOAMES: You’ve cannibalised the entire Bluefire system. Millions of pounds worth of equipment treated like... like old car parts.
DOCTOR: Rest assured, Dr Soames, if this doesn’t work it’s not something you’ll have to worry about. Let’s see how the others are getting on. (WALKING) Come on.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 100
EVE: . Oh, Doctor! I presume these cables will accommodate the power linkage between the Bluefire system and your machine?
DOCTOR: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) A series of controlled temporal surges, Miss Pritchard, yes. —
SALLY: You sure that duct tape will hold? It looks a bit dodgy.
DOCTOR: Of course it will hold. It was made in Birmingham.
SOAMES: So what exactly will happen when you switch this thing on?
DOCTOR: (FX: WALKING OVER TO SPOT) With any luck the Kalarash will manifest right about... (STOPPING) .. here.
SALLY: Manifest? Become solid, you mean?
DOCTOR: (CALLING) Everybody, gather round again.
JEROME: (FX: AS HE AND OTHERS GATHER ROUND DOCTOR) Aye-aye, looks like it’s showtime.
DOCTOR: Now. The entity is currently composed of a series of slivers in incremental time. I’ve constructed a kind of time magnet, designed to draw it out into the open.
SOAMES: (INCREDULOUSLY) Incremental time?
DOCTOR: Cracks so minute they don’t officially exist.
SALLY: You mean the entity has... divided itself up? Dispersed itself?
DOCTOR: Like a vast number of microscopic iron filings stuck between the time-cracks. When I switch on, temporal energy from the
TARDIS: will drag all those filings down to this one fixed point
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 101
TOBY: . and, hey presto!, our friend will appear?
DOCTOR: Precisely.
SALLY: Will it be like that thing I saw in the attic room, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Possibly.
JEROME: What thing?
SALLY: Tall and thin. Like a reflection in a fun house mirror. Dark- skinned, sort of leathery. Its face was... vicious. Animal-like. And it was surrounded by blue fire. Bathed in it.
JEROME: Nice.
EVE: What’1ll happen when it appears, Doctor?
DOCTOR: If all goes to plan, it will be contained in a temporal stasis field. Then I’1l set the TARDIS co-ordinates and... schlupp!
TOBY: ‘Schlupp’? Is that a technical term?
DOCTOR: It means that our friend will be sucked into the Vortex and expelled back into the wastelands.
SOAMES: And what if it doesn’t go according to plan?
DOCTOR: Then I suggest we run. Very fast. Now — is everyone standing well back, behind the power nexus?
JEROME: Check.
DOCTOR: Then — here we go!
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 102
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: HE SLAMS A LEVER; WARBLING ELECTRONIC SCREECH AS THE
SYSTEM: POWERS UP. IN THE FOLLOWING DIALOGUE EVERYONE IS RAISING THEIR VOICE ABOVE THE ESCALATING DIN)
DOCTOR: How are those readings, Miss Pritchard?
EVE: Stable, Doctor.
TOBY: Er... Doctor, there’s smoke coming from this connection here.
DOCTOR: Don’t worry. That’s perfectly normal.
SOAMES: (COUGHING) You realise that the sprinkler system will activate if it gets any worse?
DOCTOR: No it won’t. I’ve disabled it.
SOAMES: You’ve done what?
SALLY: Look! Something’s happening!
SALLY: (FX: FADE IN SOUNDS OF THE MI’EN KALARASH. IT IS IN TORMENT, SNARLING AND WRITHING)
RACHEL: Oh my — [God!]
TOBY: Is that thing real?
JEROME: It’s just like you said, Sally. The blue fire and everything.
SALLY: Doctor, the system’s overloading!
DOCTOR: Just a few more seconds. It’s almost through! (SUDDEN ALARM) Miss Pritchard! Eve! No, don’t touch that connection!
DOCTOR: (FX: THE ELECTRONIC SCREECH SUDDENLY SUBSIDES, DIES. HEAVY BREATHING OF THE MI’EN KALARASH; CRACKLE OF BLUE FIRE)
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 103
RACHEL: What happened?
SALLY: (ANXIOUSLY) Doctor...?
SOAMES: It’s Eve. She broke the connection.
DOCTOR: (OUTRAGED) Miss Pritchard! What have you done? (NO ANSWER) Miss Pritchard!
TOBY: She can’t hear you.
RACHEL: She’s in some kind of trance.
SOAMES: Eve! Speak to us!
SOAMES: (FX: THE MI’EN KALARASH ROARS, A HIDEOUS, DEMONIC SOUND. ACCOMPANYING THE ROAR IS A SURGING FLASH OF ELECTRICITY. THEN IT VANISHES. SILENCE)
DOCTOR: Is everyone all right?
SALLY: I think so.
JEROME: What happened?
RACHEL: Where’s that creature gone?
TOBY: Did your plan work, Doctor? Did you send it back where it came from?
DOCTOR: I’m afraid not...
DOCTOR: EVE/MI’'EN KALARASH (FX: RECOGNISABLE AS EVE, BUT GUTTURAL/DEMONIC) Ahh. Freedom. But such a puny frame. So... temporary.
SOAMES: (SHOCKED) Miss Pritchard?
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 104
JEROME: Oh, man! Look at her eyes!
JEROME: RACHEL/ TOBY /SOAMES
SALLY: They’re full of blue fire.
JEROME: It’s that thing, isn’t it, Doctor? It’s inside her.
DOCTOR: I’m afraid so. And not for the first time, I suspect. (RAISES
HIS: VOICE) Isn’t that right, Mi’en Kalarash?
HIS: EVE/MI'EN KALARASH Yes, Doctor. The human female has been preparing for this moment for over two Earth decades.
SOAMES: She’s been working with that thing?
DOCTOR: No. She’s been manipulated. Like a pawn on a chess board. Probably without even realising it was happening.
DOCTOR: EVE/MI'EN KALARASH
DOCTOR: When the human female was four years old it was struck by a car. It suffered injuries to its brain. It almost died. For a split-second, as it hovered between being and not being, it slipped between the cracks. Our minds touched.
DOCTOR: And you wormed your way in, didn’t you?
DOCTOR: EVE/MI'EN KALARASH
DOCTOR: Eve Pritchard brought a splinter of my consciousness back with her, into the world. Just the tiniest splinter, but enough to mould her thoughts into treading a particular path.
DOCTOR: A path that led you to me.
DOCTOR: EVE/MI'EN KALARASH The female is bait, Doctor. You are the... ‘big fish’.
DOCTOR: You've even gained a grasp of Earth idioms, I see. Not that you'll win any prizes for originality.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 105
SALLY: (WHISPERS) Not sure insulting it is a good idea, Doctor.
TOBY: (WHISPERS) When should we run? Should we run now?
TOBY: EVE/MI'EN KALARASH
TOBY: You can run, little human, but there is no escape. The age of man is over. I will wring every drop of misery and pain and terror out of your species before crushing this world and moving on to the next.
DOCTOR: (YAWNS) Have you finished? When you’ve heard one despotic rant, you’ve heard them all.
SOAMES: For goodness’ sake, don’t goad the thing, Doctor.
DOCTOR: It’ll do what it’s come to do anyway. We might as well have a bit of fun before we go.
DOCTOR: EVE/MI’EN KALARASH Your fun is over, Doctor.
DOCTOR: So soon?
TOBY: (NERVOUSLY) What’s it doing?
JEROME: Why’s it raising its hand like that?
SALLY: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Brace yourselves. This won’t be pleasant.
DOCTOR: (FX: FIERCE ELECTRICAL SURGE/FLASH BLENDS INTO A HOWLING/
RUSHING: ‘TIDAL WAVE’ SOUND. THIS IS SUPPLEMENTED BY...)
SOAMES: / SALLY /RACHEL/TOBY / JEROME
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 106
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: QUICK FADE UP. THE STEADY, SOOTHING HUM OF JET ENGINES IN FLIGHT)
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] (FX: APPROACHING, WHEELING DRINKS TROLLEY) Drink, sir?
DOCTOR: (DISORIENTATED) What? Oh... er, no. Thank you.
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] For you, madam?
SALLY: (DISORIENTATED) Huh? Wha...? (ASTONISHED) Miss Pritchard?
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS] I’m sorry, madam?
SALLY: (TAKING IN HER SURROUNDINGS) Doctor? What’s going on? Why are we on a plane?
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] Are you all right, madam?
DOCTOR: Perfectly fine, thank you. Just a little disorientated. Fell asleep and forgot where she was.
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] Well, if you’re sure...
DOCTOR: Absolutely. We’1ll call you if we need anything.
SALLY: Doctor, what’s going on? Why is Miss Pritchard dressed like
SALLY: that?
DOCTOR: That isn’t Miss Pritchard.
SALLY: Well, of course it is!
DOCTOR: Look at the other air hostesses.
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 107
DOCTOR WHO: 4 x EVES [AS AIR HOSTESSES ]
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: ALL OVERLAPPING SLIGHTLY — OR PERHAPS WITH A ‘WHIP-PAN’
SOUND: EFFECT TO SUGGEST SALLY LOOKING AROUND IN ALL DIRECTIONS ) (OFF, LEFT) Drink, sir?
SOUND: (OFF, RIGHT) Please, remain seated, madam.
SOUND: (OFF, AHEAD) Hand luggage should be placed in the overhead lockers, sir.
SOUND: (OFF, BEHIND) Today’s films? Certainly. Die Hard 2, Redeye, Flightplan and, of course, Snakes on a Plane. —
SALLY: But.. they’re all Miss Pritchard! Doctor, what’s happening?
RACHEL: (APPROACHING FROM OFF, CALLING BACK) No, I won’t sit down!
DOCTOR: Oh dear. (RAISES HIS VOICE) Miss McMahon! Rachel!
JEROME: (ROW IN FRONT) Doctor! You’re here too!
SOAMES: (BESIDE JEROME) We’re all here, it seems.
TOBY: (ROW BEHIND) What the hell’s going on, Doctor? Why are we on this plane?
SALLY: Why’s it just us on this plane...?
TOBY: (STANDING UP) We’ve been drugged, haven’t we? Kidnapped? (SHOUTING) Where are you taking us?
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] Sir, I really must ask you to calm down and get back in your [seat] —
TOBY: (INTERRUPTING) I will not calm down!
RACHEL: Why do you all look the same? What is this?
EVE: [AS AIR HOSTESS ] Sir, madam, please.
TOBY: Keep back! Back, or I’1l —
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 108
DOCTOR: (SHOUTING; AUTHORITATIVE) Stop! (STARTLED SILENCE) Don’t you realise what’s happening? Don’t you understand what you’re doing by behaving like frightened children?
EVE: [AS PILOT]
EVE: (TINNY; DISTORTED BY STATIC) Ladies and gentlemen, this is your pilot speaking. Welcome to Bluefire Airlines, currently cruising at an altitude of thirty-five thousand feet.
RACHEL: Now she’s flying this thing-?!?
SALLY: Ssh!
EVE: [AS PILOT]
EVE: I regret to inform you that we are about to run into a localised patch of stormy weather, during which the aircraft will be struck by lightning and plummet to the ground.
JEROME: What-?!?
EVE: [AS PILOT] Please, fasten your safety belts and prepare for a drawn-out and terrifying death. Thank you. (FX: INTERCOM OFF)
TOBY: (ASTONISHED) Was that meant to be a joke?
SOAMES: If so, it was in very poor [taste] —
SOAMES: (FX: CLAP OF THUNDER, FOLLOWED IMMEDIATELY BY A HUGE, CRACKLING FLASH OF LIGHTNING, DROWNS OUT HIS WORDS. STRICKEN ENGINES WHINE AND SHRIEK AS THE AIRCRAFT PLUMMETS FROM THE SKY)
SOAMES: /RACHEL/ TOBY / JEROME
SALLY: Doctor!
DOCTOR: (YELLING) Everyone! Close your eyes!
DOCTOR: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 109

elements.text: PART FOUR
NO REPRISE
51. EXT. DENSE JUNGLE
(FX: FADE UP JUNGLE SOUNDS — CHIRRUPING INSECTS, BIRD CRIES,
FOLIAGE. THEN THE HEAVY, PADDING FOOTSTEPS AND SOFT,
GROWL OF A TIGER)
(ALMOST HYPERVENTILATING; PANICKED WHISPER) Oh no no no no no...
FX: THE TIGER GROWLS AGAIN, CLOSER
(PANICKED WHISPER) Please don’t see me... Please...
(DISTORT — COMMUNICATING TELEPATHICALLY) Jerome. Can you hear me?
(SO SURPRISED HE SAYS OUT LOUD) Doctor? (FX: CAUSING THE TIGER TO SNARL AGAIN, ITS PADDING FOOTSTEPS CLOSING IN) (VOICE REDUCING TO A PANICKED WHISPER) Doctor, is that you?
(D) Yes. I’m inside your head. Don’t ask questions, just listen. Where are you?
(WHISPERS) I don’t know. In a jungle. It’s night-time. There’s something stalking me. I think it’s a tiger.
(D) Don’t panic, Jerome. Everything’s going to be all right. If you do exactly as I say, you’ll be fine. Do you understand?
FX: TIGER STILL PADDING, GROWLING
(WHISPERS) Yes, I.. I think so. What do you want me to do?
(D) I want you to close your eyes, walk forward and reach out your hand.
(WHISPERS) But — it’ll see me! I [can’t!]
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 110
(D, INTERRUPTING) Trust me, Jerome. You’ll be safe. I promise.
(PANTING; PREPARING HIMSELF) Okay... Okay... Here I come, Doctov...
STANDS
FX: THE TIGER REACTS, POUNCING FORWARD, ROARING
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 111
52. INT. UNDERGROUND CAVERN
(FX: FRANTIC SPLASHING AS RACHEL TREADS WATER, STRUGGLING TO
AFLOAT)
(EXHAUSTED, HER VOICE ECHOING OFF WALLS) I’m — I’m in the water! Help me! Someone! Please! He[lp] - (SPLUTTERS AS SHE
WATER, THEN GOES UNDER)
(FX: CUT TO HER POV, UNDERWATER. JUST FOR A MOMENT. THEN CUT
AS SHE RESURFACES )
(WHOOP OF SPLUTTERING BREATH) Somebody! Please! I can’t hold on much longer!
(D, COMMUNICATING TELEPATHICALLY) Rachel? Rachel, listen to me.
Doctor? Is that you? Where are you?
(D) I’m inside your mind.
Am I imagining this?
(D) No. I need you to do something for me, Rachel. Something you won’t want to do. But believe me, it’s the only way I can save you.
Just tell me... tell me what to do.
(D) I want you to give in.
What?
(D) Give in. Stop struggling. Let yourself sink.
(ANGER; DESPAIR; EXHAUSTION) What are you talking about? I can’t do that.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 112
(D) You can. You must. Let the fear go, Rachel. Close your eyes, stretch out your hand and let yourself sink.
DEEP BREATH
(D) Trust me, Rachel.
(FX: CUT BRIEFLY BACK TO UNDERWATER, CLOSING OVER RACHEL’S HEAD. QUICK FADE OUT)
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 113
53. INT. WRECKAGE OF THE CRASHED PLANE
FX: FADE UP THE CRACKLING OF FIRE
GROANS AS HE COMES TO
(D, SPEAKING TELEPATHICALLY) Dr Soames, can you hear me?
(WEAKLY) Who... who’s there?
(D) It’s me, Dr Soames. The Doctor.
Am I still alive?
(D) Oh yes. Very much so.
The plane crashed. It’s on fire. (BREAKING UP) The flames, they want to burn me...
(D) I know. Stretch out your hand, Dr Soames. Reach out towards
me.
I can’t see you for the flames!
(D) Reach out past them. Have faith.
FX: FADE
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 114
54. INT. HALL OF MIRRORS
(FX: FADE UP FAIRGROUND MUSIC, OFF; THE BLURRY CHATTER OF A
MOVING CROWD)
(TRYING TO HOLD HIMSELF TOGETHER, BUT THERE’S AN EDGE OF PANIC TO HIS VOICE) Hello? I say, is anyone there? (RAW; A BIT DESPERATE) Helloooo?
(D, COMMUNICATING TELEPATHICALLY) Toby. Hello.
(STARTLED CRY) Crikey, you made me jump. Is that you, Doctor?
(D) Yes.
Where are you? You sound very close.
(D) Inside your head. (TETCHY) Isn’t it obvious?
I don’t know. I can’t see, Doctor.
(D) Then perhaps you should open your eyes.
I can’t. I daren’t. (FEAR CREEPING BACK INTO HIS VOICE) I’m in a fairground, Doctor. In a hall of mirrors. Mirrors whichever way I turn. Looking at me. Laughing at me.
(D) Open your eyes, Toby. Face your fear.
I’m scared, Doctor. Scared of what I’ll see.
(D) Your fear is greater than the reality. That’s what the Mi’en Kalarash is feeding on, Toby — the dread, the expectation. Don’t let it win. Open your eyes.
(TERRIFIED) I can’t...
(D) You can. Trust me.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 115
O-Okay... (SURPRISE) Oh!
(D) What do you see?
I see you, Doctor. Reflected in the mirror. Is it a trick?
(D) No. It’s much simpler than that. The mirror isn’t really a mirror.
What is it then?
(D) It’s a doorway. And what would you do with a doorway that might lead you out of the darkness?
Step through it?
Exactly!
FX: TOBY STEPS FORWARD. HARD CUT TO:
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 116
55. INT. WHITE FEATURELESS ROOM
FX: STERILE ACOUSTICS
. and here we all are, at last.
(ASTONISHMENT) Oh! Hello.
RACHEL/SOAMES Toby./Private.
Hey, man.
Hi, Toby. How are you feeling?
Fine. I think. Where are we? It looks like a giant white Tupperware box.
It’s our safe place.
Safe as in...?
As in the Mi’en Kalarash can’t get to us here.
The Doctor made it. Created it with his mind.
Interesting choice of décor, Doctor. But minimalist for my tastes.
This is a rendezvous point, nothing more. A holding station. There’s no point expending precious mental energy on home comforts.
All that telepathy business, you mean? Yes, how did you do that?
Apparently we can all do it. The Doctor says it’s just a matter of tuning in to the right frequency.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 117
This is the domain of the Kalarash. Our actual bodies are still back in the lab.
We’re — what, thought-people?
Avatars, if you like. While our physical bodies lie unconscious, the entity is feeding.
What — sucking on our thoughts, like a vampire?
Not exactly, but you’ve grasped the basic concept.
And once it’s drunk its fill, it’1ll discard us?
. like empty burger boxes!
Yes.
So what do we do, Doctor? Just hide in here where it can’t find us and hope it’1ll go away?
Nothing so defeatist. No, we’re leaving. Going home.
Oh? And how are we going to get out of here? Click our heels together?
We could try that. But I thought it would be easier to use the door.
What door?
The one in the wall behind you.
SHOCKED SILENCE
I don’t see a door.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 118
Me neither.
It’s just there, flush with the wall. If you tilt your head slightly the outline is clearly visible.
Yes... Yes, I can see it!
So can I. I think.
I can’t see anything.
That’s because the Kalarash’s conditioning is still blocking your mind. Concentrate, Dr Soames. All of you, concentrate.
PAUSE
I still can’t...

(INTERRUPTING) Yes you can! The Kalarash thinks you’re stupid. Easily manipulated. But it’s wrong. Human beings are clever and determined and resourceful. And if you really want to go home, you'll see the door. All of you. Smack bang in the middle of the wall.
(EXCITED) Yes! I can see it! It is there! It really is!
(SLOWLY) Me too. I can see it too.
(QUIETLY) Dr Soames?
I.. I don’t...
(AIRILY) Your mind must be weaker than the others. Easier to manipulate. Ah, well, that’s hardly your fault.
(STUNG BY THE WORDS) No, wait! I can see it! Of course I can. That bang on the head must have affected my focus, that’s all.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page
Yes. That must have been it.
What’s on the other side, Doctor? Is it really a way out?
(STEPPING FORWARD) Let’s see, shall we?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 120
56. INT. BLUEFIRE SYSTEM OPERATIONS ROOM
(FX: DOOR OPENS; THEY ALL TUMBLE THROUGH, BUT MAKE NO PHYSICAL
— UNTIL NOTED FURTHER, THEY’RE ALL GHOST-LIKE MENTAL PROJECTIONS, SO NO FOOTSTEPS ETC)
[GHOST] I don’t believe it.
[GHOST] We’re back in the base! We are home!
[GHOST] Well... almost.
[GHOST] What do you mean?
[GHOST] Look there.
[GHOST] Good Lord!
[GHOST] It’s us!
[GHOST] Are we dead, Doctor? Are we... ghosts?
[GHOST] We're just as we were in the entity’s domain.
[GHOST] Thought-people?
[GHOST] Yes.
Hey, the door’s gone! The one we came through.
[GHOST] It was never there in the first place. I convinced you there was a door so you could break the Kalarash’s conditioning long enough to make the mental leap back to this reality.
[GHOST] You knew that was possible?
[GHOST] Well, I hoped.
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 121
[GHOST] (URGENTLY) Doctor!
[GHOST] What is it?
[GHOST] Through the glass, in that fear chamber place. It’s Miss Pritchard.
[GHOST] In the storage facility. Yes.
[GHOST]
(CALLING) Miss Pritchard. Miss P[ritchard]. (MAKES TO BANG ON
— BUT CAN’T TOUCH ANYTHING) — Oh! Can’t seem to touch the window.
[GHOST] Thought-people, remember?
[GHOST] She can’t hear you anyway, Mr Dodds. She’s in thrall to the Kalarash.
[GHOST] Why’s she just standing there?
The entity inside her is still gathering strength. Once it realises we’ve broken the conditioning, it’ll be back. Full of vim and vigour.
[GHOST] (OMINOUSLY) Yes. Something must be done.
[GHOST]

What I don’t understand is — why didn’t it kill you when you were unconscious, Doctor? I see that it’s kept us alive to feed on our trauma and fear, but you’re different. You’re a threat. You know what it is and where it comes from. And you’ve served your purpose already, by bringing it here. (PAUSE; UNCERTAINLY ) Er.. why are you looking at me like that? I’ve said something stupid, haven’t I?
[GHOST] On the contrary. Sally Morgan, you are a genius!
[GHOST] (SURPRISED) I am?
HOUSE OF BLUE FIRE by Mark Morris (FINAL) Page 122
[GHOST] That was an excellent question!
[GHOST] So what’s the answer, Doctor?
[GHOST] Isn’t it obvious?
[GHOST] Not to us mere mortals.
[GHOST ] The Kalarash hasn’t killed me because it can’t!
